model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
Your job is to judge if MEMORY contains helpful past information for a language model, representing Child, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

If the DIALOUGE CONTEXT does not require the model to utilize past information for response generation, say "N/A".
Say "Yes" if MEMORY contains such helpful information and say "No" if it dose not.
Provide a brief explanation for your judgement.

[Format Regulation]
Generate your output below OUTPUT using the following format:
Brief explanation: your explanation
Judgement: "Yes", "No", or "N/A"

[Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
You know, I always valued being a good listener. It's an important skill to have in life.
Yeah, I think listening is really important too. I always feel heard when I talk to you.
That's great to hear. I think listening is especially important when people are going through a tough time. It can make a big difference to feel like someone is really hearing you.
Did you feel like that when you were in detention? Like nobody was really listening to you?
Yeah, it was tough. I felt so alone and scared, and I didn't know if anyone would understand what I was going through. But eventually, I found someone who was willing to listen and it made all the difference.
I'm glad you found someone to talk to. You know, I remember when we watched the sunrise together a few weeks ago. That was really special.
It was. I love being able to appreciate the beauty of nature. And you know, having my own place to live in the suburbs makes it even easier to do things like that.
Yeah, your house is really nice. You've always been good at taking care of yourself.
Well, I've always valued my independence. Even as a kid, I wanted to do things on my own. That's why I decided to live on my own a few years ago.

[MEMORY]
Related Evidences: (1) {'Related Topics': 'Rebuilding Life and Independence', 'Related Summaries': 'Parent talks about making changes, having their own place, and striving for independence while cherishing moments with Child.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Parent: I'm so glad I have my own place now. It may not be much, but it's mine. ### Child: I love it here too, it feels like home. ### Parent: I know I made some mistakes in the past, but I'm trying to turn my life around. ### Child: I'm proud of you, Dad. It takes a lot of courage to admit when you're wrong and make changes. ### Parent: Thank you, kiddo. I just want to make sure you have a safe and stable environment to grow up in. ### Child: I appreciate that. I love spending time with you here, especially when we have breakfast together in the backyard. ### Parent: Yes, those mornings watching the sunrise are some of my favorite memories with you. ### Child: I remember the first time we did that. You woke me up so early, but it was worth it. The sunrise was beautiful. ### Parent: I'm glad you enjoyed it. And speaking of the sunrise, have you been up early enough lately to see it? ### Child: No, not really. But maybe we can do it again one weekend soon. ### Parent: That sounds like a great plan. We can have breakfast outside again and enjoy the peace and quiet before the neighborhood wakes up. ### Child: I'm looking forward to it, Dad. I love spending time with you.' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'Enjoying Independence', 'Related Summaries': 'Parent expresses happiness about their independence and their own space while appreciating Child's support.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Child: You really seem to love that house, huh? ### Parent: I do! It's just nice to have a place that's all mine, where I can do things on my own terms. ### Child: I'm glad you're happy there. And I'm always here to help out if you need it. ### Parent: Thanks, kiddo. I appreciate that. But for now, I'm just enjoying my independence and figuring things out on my own.' }
```
